description: From Latin obsessus, perfect passive participle of obsideō (“sit on or in, remain, besiege”), from ob (“before”) + sedeō (“I sit”); see sit, session, etc.; compare assess, possess.

verbs.description: obsess (third-person singular simple present obsesses, present participle obsessing, simple past and past participle obsessed)

entries.meaning: (passive, constructed with "with") To be preoccupied with a single topic or emotion.
examples: Some people are obsessed with sports.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To dominate the thoughts of someone.
examples: Thoughts of her obsess my every waking moment.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, colloquial, construed with over) To think or talk obsessively about.
examples: Stop obsessing over it, will you!
